results.title: It feels like you're left out of the world (TEFC): experiencing learning disabilities
results.creator_credit: Barrie Angus McLean, Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and Robert Anderson Associates
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Learning Series”.
Children speak of their attitudes towards their own learning disabilities, and of the way in which their life has been affected by these disabilities. Articulates the personal and social consequences of having a learning problem - the feeling of being a failure is a classroom lesson that many of these children never forget. Shows that the children given time and special help, their problems can be overcome.

results.title: Teaching the way they learn: remediation of learning disabilities
results.creator_credit: Barrie Angus McLean, Robert Anderson, Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and Robert Anderson Associates
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Learning Series”
Dr Sam Rabinovitch explains some of the methods used in teaching children with learning disabilities due to poor listening ability or poor bodily coordination. Points out how important it is that the child learns and understands what is being taught.

results.title: Old enough but not ready: early recognition of learning disabilities
results.creator_credit: Barrie Angus McLean and Robert Anderson Associates
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Learning Series”.
Derek behaves as if he had difficulty uttering words; Eugene is unable to follow verbal instructions such as “left”, “first, “after”; Mark has yet to use his hands as though the fingers are ten distinct elements. Children of six and seven who are bright and cheerful but for various reasons are not yet able to cope with the demands made in a Grade One classroom. Dr. Sam Rabinovitch explains the advantage of early recognition of learning disabilities in children. Shows the learning and teaching difficulties of these children.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Barrie Angus McLean and Robert Anderson Associates

results.title: I'm not too famous at it: a definition of learning disabilities
results.creator_credit: Barrie Angus McLean, Robert Anderson and Canadian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Learning Series”.
The title was named by Robert, a bright nine year old, who lacks eye-hand coordination, has difficulty appreciating the characteristics of shapes and forms, has language difficulties of various kinds, who has poor gross motor coordination and other problems. While defining and describing these learning deficits indirectly shows somthing of the process of remediation.

results.title: Wood ducks and tyre-kickers
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “Landscape with figures: the art of Australia”.
One of a series in which Robert Hughes surveys Australia’s art from the time of the first fleet to the present day. In this final program, Hughes assesses the commercial and social backgrounds against which Australian art operates and looks at a government sponsored exhibition of 10 artists in Paris in 1974.

results.title: Directions
results.creator_credit: Brian Adams and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “Landscape with figures: the art of Australia”.
One of a series in which Robert Hughes surveys Australia’s art from the time of the first fleet to the present day. This episode focuses on Twentieth Century landscape imagery, the leaders of this style were Olsen, Rose and Smith. Other artists whose work is discussed include Godfrey Miller, Ian Fairweather, Fred Williams and Brett Whitely. Written and narrated by Robert Hughes.
